have described myself as always having been embued with a fervent longing
penetrate the secrets of nature. In spite
the intense labour and wonderful discoveries of modern philosophers,
studies discontented and unsatisfied. Sir Isaac Newton is said
have avowed that he felt like
child picking up shells beside the great and unexplored ocean of truth. Those of his successors in each branch

natural philosophy with whom I was acquainted, appeared even to my boy’s apprehensions, as tyros engaged in the same pursuit.

The untaught peasant beheld the elements around him, and was acquainted with their practical uses. The most learned philosopher knew little more. He had partially unveiled the face of Nature,
her immortal lineaments were still a wonder and a mystery. He might dissect, anatomise, and give names; but,
to speak of a final cause, causes
their secondary and tertiary grades were <pb n="27" xml:id="F1831_v_043"/>utterly unknown to him. I had gazed upon the fortifications and impediments that seemed to keep human beings from entering

citadel of nature, and rashly and ignorantly I had repined.

But here were books, and here were men who had penetrated deeper
took their word for all that they averred, and I became their disciple.
